titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Edward Bell Krumbhaar (1882-1966) was a distinguished pathologist and cardiac physiologist, as well as one of Philadelphia’s leading historians of medicine. A founder of both the Section on Medical History of the College of Physicians and the American Association of the History of Medicine (AAHM), Krumbhaar also served as President of the College and of the AAHM. Throughout his career he published English translations of works originally in French, German and Italian. Besides his own work, he is best remembered by historians for his revised translation of Arturo Castiglioni’s History of Medicine (1941).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Edward B. Krumbhaar. Materials relating to Krumbhaar’s University of Pennsylvania career include: correspondence; syllabi and exams; lecture notes; research notes; minutes from various hospital committees; reports; reprints; and photographs. (1910-1956). College of Physician of Philadelphia materials include correspondence and minutes from his tenure as Vice President, President, and as a member of the Library Committee and Council. (1921-1943). Other materials in the collection include: general correspondence, 1907-1962; correspondence related to editing of Clio Medica, 1929-1943; correspondence related to editing of American Journal of Medical Science, 1935-1936 and 1941-1942; minutes and correspondence regarding appointments from Chestnut Hill Hospital, 1937-1938; information from the Army Medical Reserve Corps, including a course manual, and a small amount of correspondence, 1914-1936; and manuscripts, drafts, and reprints, including a set of bound reprints, 1908-1955.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
